history.content:
I took CS70 over the summer and found it pretty difficult, but I've heard others say it was manageable.  For me, I felt as if I never had the chance to truly digest the material, since there was lecture + discussion Mon-Thurs.  I was always kind of understanding things on a surface level during the week, then using the weekends to finish problem sets/spend time on my other commitments (I was also working/had practice/commuted from home every day).  Touching on prereqs, I had taken Math 54 before I took CS70, although I don't believe it's really necessary.  I think the department is moving towards EE16A/EE16B being the golden standard for "mathematical maturity," so maybe take a took at some of their websites and see how you feel about the level of difficulty.

tldr- It's totally doable if you don't mind putting in a lot of work

Hi all! I'm a freshman trying to double major and was wondering what the workload would be to take a reading-intensive introductory humanities course along with CS 70 in the summer.

I'd love to hear about the experiences of people who have taken CS 70 over the summer.

I know CS 70 doesn't have specific prereqs, but is it doable to take the class with experience only in Math 1A, 1B and CS 61A? Or would it be advisable to take other math/ CS/ EE courses before taking CS 70?

Thank you!
history.subject: Taking CS 70 and a reading-intensive humanities course during the summer?
